name: tsuga-canadensis
country-or-region-of-origin: North Central and Eastern U.S.A., Eastern Canada
wildlife-value: It provides winter and extreme weather coverage.  Red crossbills and small mammals eat the seeds.  Ruffled grouse eat the buds and white-tailed deer browse the foilage in winter.  It is an important thermal cover component along streams for amphibians and fish. It also provides cover and shelter for turkey and white-tailed deer.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: This tree is moderately resistant to damage from deer.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: The young female cones are green, oval, and have closed scales. As the cones mature, they are brown and 3/4-inch long. The scales will open to release their seeds.
flower-description: No flowers. Pollen cones yellow rounded bumps that resemble a blackberry 1/8" across are found in groups near the tips of branches.
leaf-description: The leaves are small ½-inch glossy needles that have a white underside in 2 opposite rows.  Its needles are attached by slender stalks ending with woody pads.  The margins minutely dentate, especially toward the apex. The linear green needles are spirally arranged around the branch.  Along the main branches, some needles are laying on their backs.
bark-description: On mature trees, the bark is reddish-brown to grayish-brown with a thick, scaly, or ridged surface with irregular fissures.
stem-description: Twigs yellow-brown, densely pubescent. Stems slender, gray-brown in color; buds are very small.
uses: The cambium is used by Native Americans for breads and soups as well as with dried fruit and animal fat for pemmican. The leaves, which are high in vitamin C, are also used for tea. The bark was once used for tannin for leather production.
